mergesort

Class Merge

  • java.lang.Object
    • mergesort.Merge

  • public class Merge
extends java.lang.Object
    This class implements the mergesort algorithm for an Array; there are 3 main methods:

    - mergesort, which takes a single array as input and sorts it, calling itself a mergesort methods which takes in input the range over which the array must be sorted

    - mergesort, which takes an array and 2 parameters which specify the range of the array to be sorted; to sort the entire array, the first mergesort method can be used, as it calls this method with boundaries 0 and array length - 1;

    - merge, which takes an array and three parameters which specify the parts of the array to merge (these parts need to be sorted);

    There are two version of the above methods: one which takes an array of Rectangles and one which takes an array of a generic type T which extends Comparable<T> The first is tweaked to let the changes in the array be animated, the latter simply sorts the supplied array
    Author:
    Andrea

    • Method Detail

      • mergesort

        public static <T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>> void mergesort(T[] A)
        This method takes an array of a Comparable type T and sorts it.
        It calls another mergesort method which takes both the array and the range over which the array must be sorted. It's convenient in that it requires just the array to be sorted as a parameter, unlike the other mergesort method
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the array elements; must extend the Comparable interface
        Parameters:
        A - An array of type T

      • mergesort

        public static <T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>> void mergesort(T[] A,
                                                                 java.lang.Integer first,
                                                                 java.lang.Integer last,
                                                                 T[] B)
        This method sorts the array over the specified range with the mergesort algorithm.
        It basically splits the array in two parts, orders them and then merges them; an array of 1 element is considered ordered. It has complexity Θ(nlogn)
        Parameters:
        A - The array to be sorted; the type T of the array elements must extend the Comparable interface
        first - The first index of the range over which the array will be sorted
        last - The last index of the range over which the array will be sorted

      • mergesort

        public static void mergesort(javafx.scene.shape.Rectangle[] rectangles)
        Same as mergesort(Comparable[]) in functionality.
        It differs from it in that there are some modifications necessary to animate the mergesort algorithm.
        Parameters:
        A - The array of Rectangles to be sorted.

      • mergesort

        public static void mergesort(javafx.scene.shape.Rectangle[] A,
                             java.lang.Integer first,
                             java.lang.Integer last)
        Same as Merge#mergesort(Comparable[], Integer, Integer) in functionality, differs from it for the same reason mergesort(Rectangle[]) differs from mergesort(Comparable[]) (see mergesort(Rectangle[]) for details)
        Parameters:
        A - The array of Rectangles to be sorted
        first - The first end of the range the array must be sorted on
        last - The last end of the range the array must be sorted on

      • isSorted

        public static <T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>> boolean isSorted(T[] A)
        Simple method that returns true if the given array is sorted
        Type Parameters:
        T - The type of the Array must extend the Comparable interface
        Parameters:
        A - The array to be checked
        Returns:
        true if the given array is sorted, false otherwise
